"Sodium thiosulfate."

And considering you're dealing with bromine, I'm not surrpised.

Sodium thiosulfate is used as a photographic fixer. That's what's used to strip off the unexposed emulsion off photographic film, essentially silver bromide, leaving just the metallic silver brought out by the developer stage. The unexposed areas end up being clear on negative film.

Im pursuing a degree in chemistry and I am definitely not at Nile's level yet, so I wouldn't even try making this lol, but I have made some pretty cool stuff in laboratory settings. I told my mom I wanted to make a cloud chamber (which requires dry ice and 90% or higher isopropyl alcohol) and is very safe. But my was very against the idea at first even when I would assure her that its safe lol. If whoever reads this doesn't know what a cloud chamber is, essentially it allows you to visualize subatomic particles because it creates a path through the alcohol vapor in the chamber. It is infinitely safer than this bromine experiment though, but comparing that to this bromine experiment is like comparing apples to oranges. When I was in highschool in AP chem my teacher let me forge a dagger with thermite (in a lab setting), and try and purify the iron with different acids and whatnot.

Next time you have trouble with a pump working, try cycling it on and off while at the same time giving it vibration from a hammer or a light drop on the table. This causes the impeller to become loose again if anything is stuck in it or it's just seized shut. My experience with pumps is that this will fix a seized or non-working pump about 90% of the time, as long as the motor or power source is working obviously.

Bromine combines violently with the alkali metals and with phosphorus, arsenic, aluminum, and antimony but less violently with certain other metals. Bromine displaces hydrogen from saturated hydrocarbons and adds to unsaturated hydrocarbons, though not as readily as chlorine does.

The most stable oxidation state of the element is −1, in which bromine occurs naturally. But oxidation states of 0 (elemental bromine, Br2), +1 (hypobromite, BrO−), +3 (bromite, BrO−2), +5 (bromate, BrO−3), and +7 (perbromate, BrO−4) are also known. The first ionization energy of bromine is high, and compounds containing bromine in positive oxidation numbers are stabilized by appropriate ligands, mainly oxygen and fluorine. Compounds with the oxidation numbers +1, +3, +4, +5, and +7 all contain covalent bonds.

Production And Use

The chief commercial source of bromine is ocean water, from which the element is extracted by means of chemical displacement (oxidation) by chlorine in the presence of sulfuric acid through the reaction
Equation.
The product of the reaction is a dilute solution of bromine, from which the element is removed by blowing air through it. The free bromine is then mixed with sulfur dioxide, and the mixed gases are passed up a tower down which water is trickling. The following reaction takes place in the tower:

Equation.

resulting in a mixture of acids that is much richer in bromide ion than seawater. A second treatment with chlorine liberates bromine, which is freed from chlorine and purified by passage over moist iron filings.

Commercial bromine generally contains up to 0.3 percent chlorine. It is usually stored in glass bottles or in barrels coated with lead or Monel metal.

The industrial usage of bromine had been dominated by the compound ethylene bromide (C2H4Br2), which once was added to gasoline with tetraethyl lead to prevent deposition of lead in the engine. Since the renunciation of leaded gasoline, bromine compounds have mainly been used in flame retardants, but ethylene bromide is still an important compound because of its use to destroy nematodes and other pests in soils. Bromine is also used in the production of catalysts, such as aluminum bromide.

Bromine has other uses. , as in making various dyes and the compounds tetrabromoethane (C2H2Br4) and bromoform (CHBr3), which are used as liquids in gauges because of their high specific gravity. Until the development of barbiturates in the early 20th century, bromides of potassium, sodium, calcium, strontium, lithium, and ammonium were used widely in medicine because of their sedative action. Silver bromide (AgBr), an important component of photographic film, is, like silver chloride and iodide, light sensitive. Traces of potassium bromate (KBrO3) are added to wheat flour to improve baking. Other bromine compounds of significance include hydrogen bromide (HBr), a colourless gas used as a reducing agent and a catalyst in organic reactions. A solution of the gas in water is called hydrobromic acid, a strong acid that resembles hydrochloric acid in its activity toward metals and their oxides and hydroxides.

Analysis

A sensitive test for bromine is the reaction with fluorescein to give a deep red colour caused by bromination of the organic molecule, or by its reaction with fuchsine dyes in the presence of sulfurous acid, to give a deep blue colour. A more common test involves heating the sample with dilute sulfuric acid in the presence of potassium dichromate; the bromine is then extracted with chloroform, and, upon addition of potassium iodide, the pink colour of iodine appears. The presence of bromine may also be recognized by the evolution of hydrogen bromide containing some brown bromine vapour when a solid sample is treated with concentrated sulfuric acid. Alternatively, chlorine may be added to an aqueous solution of a sample containing bromide, causing development of a brown colour (free bromine)

You might think lots of regulation and government oversight keeps you safe..

But the sad and unavoidable fact, is that they only serve to restrict honest people who in these cases only want to learn, become experienced, and possibly even make an actual living off of doing these things..

do we really think that 10 years from now, it’ll even be possible to start something like a YouTube channel on this stuff? It’ll be another situation where the “elites” control all of the knowledge and ability to do simple or advanced chemistry, because they’re already the established people... it’s sad to me. Just like when I began programming... and felt different than I ever ever had. I felt like I was literally getting a natural “high” off of doing something I loved.. but as the years have gone by, things I used to do have become so easy, trivial, and pre-packaged that any 12 year old with a free app can do whatever I had to do myself from scratch.

I guess my end point is, people passionate about things like this are quickly being pushed out of their passion because of the “big guy”. And, people who used to be able to make a living off of a skill they had, no longer can, because an app or a robot does it better or cheaper than they can.. we’re facing a big big problem when the majority of people can’t make a living, and only a few rich or privileged people make the majority of all income.

Fun fact: If you electrolyze salt water to near maximum chlorine solubility, use a very low heat with a distillation chamber to distill out the chlorine, and the literally just add the chlorine gas to a maximum solubility solution of sodium bromide, you have successfully done the same thing more safely and cost effectively... as well as more easily. Disclaimer: This is still a terrible idea, and it gives you double the risk of dying. (Not actually. Still super dangerous, though.)
I just realized after watching the video almost 2 months after I initially watched it that the method used is exactly the same as one I "created" to make bromine with similar chemicals. Also, I forgot that I had hypobromous acid, not hydrobromic acid. (I of course didn't attempt anything because I kept forgetting to even write a spreadsheet on the reaction so I didn't know the essential components.)
You can also make bromine by making hypobromous acid, which is made by mixing aqeous solutions of both sodium hypochlorite and hydrogen bromide together, which will produce sodium chloride and hypobromous acid. The hypobromous acid can be isolated via boiling on low heat, and the sodium chloride will not vaporize. The water that will partly vaporize is not an issue, as you next should mix the hypobromous acid with water. Unfortunately, it is unclear weather it is a solid, liquid, or gas at room temperature, but due to what causes it's instability, it is likely a gas, so mixing it will water is for safer storage. Simply add water ice and wait for it to melt. Repeat until there is very much a lack of vapor forming. Now, it will simply slowly decompose from ultraviolet light. This will produce bromine. It is a (NOT extremely) slow, but worthwhile process, which can achieve significant production of bromine on an industrial scale.

I’m in some aquarium groups and there is a device called an algae doctor that is sold to kill algae. It claims that it uses electrolysis to kill bacteria/algae in aquariums but it also sometimes kills fish.

We’re not chemists, so we don’t know what’s actually causing the fish to die, and there doesn’t seem to be anyone who has tested it and explained what is happening.

I know this is a long shot and is outside of what you normally do, but if you know anyone that does this work that we could send a device to it would be really helpful to us.

I’m not in any way affiliated with Algae Doctor, I’m a hobbyist that wants fewer pets to die.

I don't want to be "that guy," but as a chemical stockroom manager, your chemical storage looks very unsafe. The chemical bottles stored on thin, lipless shelves above 3ft is a huge hazard, and the bottles of propane and MAP should NEVER be stored sideways in an enclosed drawer, especially with the ignitor still attached. The latter is a massive leak & explosion risk, and the former is a drop and spill risk. Please think about changing at least these two things, the risk of chemical exposure or unintended reactions is high for your lab, and safety is the #1 most important thing you should consider as a scientist.

I can understand wanting to go back to the old, more difficult way that makes you think more about what you're doing and put more care and attention into it. I dabble in programming, but instead of using a common language like Python or LUA or even C++, I prefer to use older, and sometimes more difficult languages, especially assembly. I especially enjoy coding assembly for the 8052, which is a microcontroller from the 1980's. I also dabble in 8086 assembly, which is an Intel CPU again from the 80's. And of course, I like to dabble in 6502 assembly, which is the CPU that powered the original Nintendo, the Commodore 64 and many other iconic pieces of technology. I also like to play around in a 64 bit port of QBasic, which was a variant of BASIC again from the 80's, or early 90's.

I could use an Arduino or C++ or something similar that's been kept up to date over the years. But I prefer the challenge of working with say, the 256 bytes of memory that an 8052 has, or the 8 bit numbers of a 6502. And for those who don't know, 8 bit numbers are no larger than 255. So if you want to do math on a larger number, you've gotta do some tricky programming, rather than just saying "okay now multiply 1253 by 439. That's half the fun for me.

reminds me of Heisenberg reminiscing of his times as Walter White! Now, this is actually one of my strongest understandings of chemistry, as I used to work as a service tech in the pool industry for many years. We dealt with a lot of these chemicals and reactions. Now, I agree, this man has enough knowledge of chemistry, I have enough knowledge of this chemistry from years of experience in the trade. But I must echo the "DO NOT TRY THIS AT HOME!!!" part. Here is the ugly of it.

Pool chemicals can be extremely violent and volatile if "fooled around with" improperly. When I first started, we had some guys that would screw off on the job. One day, while cleaning the shop, they mixed two types of shock together, and closed the bucket. It was loaded on the truck, the next morning, I opened the lid, and leaned over the tailgate to see how much I had before leaving. no sooner did I lean over, my vision went black and my eyes watered, I began coughing, and couldnt for the life of me take a breath. I was convinced I was dying. someone came up and sprayed water in my face and I gasped, taking sips, and finally was able to breathe. It began smoking in the container. To this day, I have a cough that won't go away. My brother, being a new homeowner with a pool, ran out of trichlor tabs, so instead, put powdered chlorine in the auto chlorinator, no sooner did he seal the cap on and turn his back, the slow trickle of water coming in had activated the chlorine and BAM! blew the vessel apart in every direction around the yard along with heavily chlorinated water, and plastic shrapnel gave him a pretty decent gash down his side. He got lucky. I have walked into equipment rooms where a new cleaning guy forgot to open a valve on a chlorinator when he was done reloading and I had to clear people out of the area, because the heat and pressure stretched and ballooned the chlorinator to three times its normal size.

These chemicals can severely injure, disfigure, or KILL you or others around if you don't know what you are doing.

When I was at school, we had a practical chemistry exam in which you were given 3 substances and were allowed to do whatever we wanted to identify them - dissolve them in various solvents, recrystallise them, burn them to look at the flame, and react them with reagents in the school lab, for which they let us use a fume hood.
Anyway, the first kid to get to the fume hood did not turn it on, and no one else bothered to check when they went either, so 15 different pairs of kids mixed god knows what in this hood until a noxious brown vapour began to fill the room, causing the entire science block to be evacuated.

While you're probably greatly aware, youtube is a visual platform. This I feel the more visually noticable a chemical process is, the more engaging the video's will become. Bromine is visually great with it's vapour clouds and thick black colour. Or something like your uranium glass stuff was also great because the end product glows or absorbs energy. In saying that, most chemically exciting processes use clear or white liquids, powders and produce mostly clear gasses.
Bearing the above in mind, are their any chemically interesting processes that can be set up and done over a long period of time that with the help of a time lapse camera can also have a visually interesting effect? Long time I'm thinking of weeks or months. Similar to grass growth, and chemicals that make the grass change colour.

'Everyone said I'd die doing it, but I was careful, and I managed it without injury.'  'So now I'm going to push my luck and do it again.'  So what's bromine used for, anyway?  I've no intention to ever make any, just watch out of curiosity.  I've heard of bromine, but the only use I can think of is 'brominated vegetable oil' which is one of the ingredients in Mountain Dew.  Your parents are FANTASTIC parents, by the way.  Too many parents approach their task of parenting as 'I have to protect my kid from all dangerous things'.  They completely neglect their actual duty to PARENT the kid and encourage them in becoming a capable independent adult.  Your dads approach of 'if you were a musician, you'd be playing music, if a football play you'd be exercising, etc' is quite right!  I am a software engineer and during my teen years, I wasn't working on chemistry, I was working on and playing with and exploring creating software.  You asked your mom 'what if I was just overly confident in my abilities?' but I think that's where them knowing you as a person nearly as well as you know yourself comes in.  Parents know whether their kid has a tendency to either over or underestimate their own capacities, whether they are careful or reckless, and stuff like that by the time the kid is 10 probably.  Being careful, modest, reasonable, etc are pretty fundamental personality traits and they don't just get isolated to one area in a persons life.  You probably haven't wrecked a lot of cars, hurt a lot of friends, gotten into a lot of fights you started, etc, and they correctly figured you'd bring that demeanor to chemistry where you wouldn't just be careful but smart enough to research and recognize and respect the places where danger actually existed.

Otherwise, it could accidentally leak out onto mine or my friends' skins and we could totally forget about passing any tests, or what normal felt like for the next week, at least. Or forever, depending on the amount... Those are some of the very few drugs out there, that one could indulge in almost every weekend, have truckloads of fun, never feel like it's getting old, and still, love school, maintain insatiable curiosity for learning new things, and even graduate with honours. I miss those days so much now. Not so sure Bromine would have replaced even 0.1% of those experiences for me.

I died from bromine poisoning i made in my parents garage

Back in school, our chemistry teacher pulled out bromine and told us when she would drop it, the whole school needs to be evacuated and I thought she is joking, because why would a school have such dangoures chemicals?

Today I ask me why the heck has the school such deadly chemicals. The most dangerous things our class handled was alcohol and fire. For some weird reason, mostly our teacher made experiments and a lot of boring theory. I mean someone was able to break glass with boiling water, let the gas running without a flame and some idiot (me) tried to hold alcohol in fire. For my defense, we needed to mix some chemicals and one should be put into fire. Me and my group thought every mixture should be put into fire. I was thinking putting the mixture with alcohol into fire would be a bad idea but the teacher has a reason why we should do it.

Overall I don't know why we needed such chemicals. The highlight every 10th grader told us was that they made wine or some sort of wine and they where allowed to drink it (the drinking age here starts at 16, so no big deal). We didn't done it, because we didn't had chemistry in 10th grade.

Yes, sodium thiosulfate is the original “hypo” aka fixer of photography. It will wash away leftover AgCl and AgBr salts from a gelatine silver emulsion, thus making the image stable (which is made of reduced metallic silver from those salts). More rapid fixers employ ammonium thiosulfate, with the same effect and work better on AgI salts.

comment_by: Random Experiments Int. - Experiments and syntheses
comment_text: It's fascinating to see so many things I had to deal with in the past, but also things that I still have to. Working with bromine, without a fume hood is a pain. The safety issue is so relatable and still something I have to think about very often. I can relate to the strange feeling in the past, but I know today, that it was the feeling of doing something that is completely new and nobody can tell you something about it. You're kind of like a scientist doing research for yourself and if anything goes wrong you are alone, which gives you the whole responsibility. So, you have to think about all the scenarios. And back then I always had the feeling of doing something that is only barely legal, even though I knew everything was fine, because I have actually been looking up a few laws, back then. And I sometimes still do it. It's a strange feeling to have access to so much more, than what I had, back then and I can only dream of renting a lab. Nevertheless, it's god to have dreams that motivate you. Thanks for sharing this experience! Can't wait to see the new lab!

Story time: When I was a freshman in college, I was taking a chemistry class in which the professor was doing a demonstration involving a test tube, liquid bromine, and aluminum foil. She had a student pushing shards of the foil into the test tube of bromine, and the reaction got out of hand. The bromine began evaporating, filling the lecture hall with a noxious brown vapor. I'll never forget the look of horror on the professor's face when she moved to leave the room using a fire exit door, only to find that it was locked. At that point, the fire alarm started going off, and the entire seven-story building had to be evacuated.
